table.name: mem
table.column: This refers to the sound, and not to any letter or glyph.

table.name: mem
table.column: behave as, act in the manner of

The example sentence from {TKDA:src} comes from {TNG - A Matter of Honor:src}. The script had {nepwI' ghaH:sen@@nep:v, -wI':v, ghaH:n}, but the actor flubbed the line and {Da:v:nolink} and {-ba':v:suff} were created to backfit the spoken sentence.
{SkyBox 99:src} had only the Klingon text. The English and German text come from {SkyBox 01:src} and {SkyBox 95:src}, respectively, which were just translations into those languages of the same card.

table.name: mem
table.column:
{SoH:n}:{ghaH:n}/{'oH:n}/{chaH:n}/{bIH:n} = {Da-:v:pref,nolink}
When used with {-lu':v}, this prefix means "Someone (indefinite subject) does something to you".

table.name: mem
table.column: In Klingon, when one lives at a place, he or she is thought of as occupying or inhabiting it. That is, he or she is not seen as doing something at a location, but rather as doing something to it.[2]

table.name: mem
table.column: "Ichabod Mudd" ({'IqbaD:sen:nolink}) was the name of a character on the Captain Midnight radio serial.

table.name: mem
table.column: be not attentive, be distracted, lack focus
This applies to a person who is not focused on the task at hand.[1, p.149]

table.name: mem
table.column: [1] {DSC - Battle at the Binary Stars:src}, [2] {Saarbrücken qepHom'a' 2019:src}

table.name: mem
table.column: This word has never been given a formal definition. In {KGT:src}, it appears in the body only as a part of {nISwI' DaH:n:nolink} "disruptor banks" and {pu'DaH:n:nolink} "phaser banks". On the {BoP:src} poster, it appears in {So'wI' DaH:n:nolink} "Cloak Array", {begh DaH:n:nolink} "Deflector Array", {pIvghor lIngwI' DaH:n:nolink} "Warp Generation Array", {pIvchem lIngwI' DaHmey:n:nolink} "Warp Field Generation Arrays", {'o' chuyDaH:n:nolink} "Aft Thrusters", {Hong boq chuyDaH:n:nolink} "Impulse Fusion Thrusters".

table.name: mem
table.column: I must wash my hair now.
This is something you might say to turn down someone's romantic overtures.

table.name: mem
table.column:
While both {DaHjaj:n:nolink} and {jajvam:n} mean "today", they are not quite interchangeable. {DaHjaj:n:nolink} (but not {jajvam:n:nolink}) is used as the time element in a sentence: {DaHjaj romuluSngan vIHoHpu':sen:nolink} "today I killed a Romulan".[2]
As the subject of a sentence, {jajvam:n:nolink} is more typically found, though {DaHjaj:n:nolink} is not impossible. Compare: ▶ {nI' jajvam:sen:nolink} "this day is long" ▶ {nI' DaHjaj:sen:nolink} "today is long"[2]
{DaHjaj:n:nolink} also behaves as a noun in such noun-noun constructions as {DaHjaj gheD:n} "today's prey", a term often heard in Klingon restaurants with a meaning comparable to "catch of the day".[2]
{DaHjaj:n:nolink} is also used with words indicating a time of day to refer to that portion of the current day. For example, {DaHjaj ram:n}, literally "today's night", means "tonight".[2]
As a time element, {DaHjaj:n} precedes any adverbials.[1, sec. 6.7]

table.name: mem
table.column: dish in a restaurant, "catch of the day"

table.name: mem
table.column: The sentence {tlhIngan yoH Daj verengan yoH qetlh:sen:nolink} on {KGT p.179:src} suggests that {Daj:v:nolink} and {qetlh:v:nolink} are opposites.

table.name: mem
table.column: May you die before you are captured.

table.name: mem
table.column:
This is "dull".
The sentence {tlhIngan yoH Daj verengan yoH qetlh:sen:nolink} on {KGT p.179:src} suggests that {Daj:v:nolink} and {qetlh:v:nolink} are opposites. The example sentence suggests that {Dal:v:nolink} is absence of {Daj:v:nolink}.

table.name: mem
table.column: regard as, view as, consider (treat somebody like)

▶ {HumanvaD 'urwI' wIDam:sen@@Human:n, -vaD:n, 'urwI':n, wI-:v, Dam:v} "We treat the human as a traitor" ▶ {'urwI' ghaH 'e' vIDam:sen@@'urwI':n, ghaH:n, 'e':n, vI-:v, Dam:v} "I consider him (to be) a traitor"

table.name: mem
table.column: This is the closest Klingon equivalent to a hippo.[1]

table.name: mem
table.column: This refers to a device worn over the ears with both ears covered, with a band across the head, so that only the user can listen to something. The device Uhura wears is a {teS HablI':n}.
It was clarified during the Q & A session that this word does not apply to earbuds.

table.name: mem
table.column: This means to make (an image) less blurry.[1]
It was confirmed that this is transitive during the Q & A session, and that one can focus one's eyes.

table.name: mem
table.column: ▶ {lojmIt poSDaq Daq pagh.:sen} ▶ {bIDaqchu' 'ej jagh De' lI' DaSuq.:sen@@bI-:v, Daq:v, -chu':v, 'ej:conj, jagh:n, De':n, lI':v:1, Da-:v, Suq:v} "Intercept useful enemy information."[2]

table.name: mem
table.column: ▶ {chenmoHlu'meH Daq:n} ▶ {wej Daqmey yIHeD.:sen:nolink} "Go back three spaces."[2]

table.name: mem
table.column: This word has appeared only in a deleted scene from the 2009 {Star Trek:src} movie. In the released edit of the deleted scene, the actor clearly says {Daq'a':n:nolink}, but there is no official transcript of the line in Klingon. Its meaning comes from context, but it is really just the noun {Daq:n} plus the suffix {-'a':n:suff}.

table.name: mem
table.column: On {TKD p.172:src}, "I'm lost" is given as {jIHtaHbogh naDev vISovbe'.:sen:nolink} On {PK:src}, "I'm lost" is given in both regular and clipped Klingon versions, the latter of which is {DaqwIj Sovbe'.:sen:nolink}

table.name: mem
table.column:
In Klingon, this is a command rather than a question. It literally means, "Identify the place where you live!"[1]
An acceptable way to phrase this demand as a question is {nuq DaDab?:sen:nolink}[1]

table.name: mem
table.column: This normally refers to a water well, but could be for other substances. It refers to a well which is constructed (or dug), rather than naturally occurring. If clarity is needed, one can say {bIQ Daqrab:n@@bIQ:n, Daqrab:n}.

table.name: mem
table.column: There is an idiom, {jej; Daqtagh rur}.
{SkyBox 2:src} is about this weapon, though it's never actually named on it. See the example under {taj:n:nolink}.

table.name: mem
table.column: This refers to a person with an "icy" demeanor, especially a tough negotiator. It is not clear whether this is a native Klingon word or a borrowed Trill or Kriosian word or phrase meaning "ice man," but, in any case, this is the Klingon pronunciation.[1]
The requested word was "d'akturak", which is how the definition appears in the new words list. The "ice man" part was added for clarification.

table.name: mem
table.column: This refers to the beverage only. For the dried-up mixture used to brew tea, see {Qenvob:n}.
"Dark". Also, Darjeeling is a type of tea.
▶ {Hoch vor Dargh wIb.:sen:nolink} "Sour tea cures everything."[2]

table.name: mem
table.column: ▶ {Hoch vor Dargh wIb.:sen:nolink} "Sour tea cures everything."[1]

table.name: mem
table.column: In {TNK:src}, "cup and saucer" is translated as {Dargh HIvje' jengva' je:n@@Dargh HIvje':n, jengva':n, je:conj}.

table.name: mem
table.column: Someone on the show didn't like the sound of {DeQ:n} and added something to the middle to make a new word.

table.name: mem
table.column: The movie "Das Boot" is a submarine thriller which inspired some of the cloaked ship battle sequences in Star Trek.

table.name: mem
table.column: This refers to a line in "Lady Madonna" by The Beatles: "Monday's child has learned to tie his bootlace."

table.name: mem
table.column: This word is never followed by the locative suffix {-Daq:n:suff}. ({TKD 3.3.5:src})
▶ {qatlh Dat DI tu'lu', tlhIngan?:sen:nolink} "Why is there rubble everywhere, Klingon?"[2]

table.name: mem
table.column:
This applies to movement by the whole body or thing to the left or right.
It's not used if a person's feet stay put but the body leans left or right, for which see {ler:v}.
This verb can be applied to aircraft, for which see {Dav:v:2}.[1]

table.name: mem
table.column: sway (aircraft moves to the side without yawing)
This is just the verb {Dav:v:1} applied to aircraft.

table.name: mem
table.column: This word covers the same semantic ground as the verbs {HoQ:v} and {Qaq:v} (but not really {mIl:v}).

table.name: mem
table.column: Watch the "A Klingon Christmas Carol" trailer where this is used: {YouTube video:url:http://youtu.be/5Nc5t9AZYsM}
The term {DawI' yaH:n:nolink} was used for "stage" in Hamlet. This was long before {much yaH:n:nolink} was revealed.
▶ {qatlh tlhIngan lut luja' tera'ngan DawI'pu'lI'?:sen:nolink} "Why are your earthling actors telling a Klingon story?"[1]

table.name: mem
table.column: This refers to the viscous, sweet fluid produced from plant nectar.[1]
Backwards: Rick ({rIq:sen:nolink}) Moranis was the star of "Honey, I Shrunk the Kids" ({yaD:n:3}).

table.name: mem
table.column: This is an ingredient in {ro'qegh'Iwchab:n}, which will turn out badly if the plant is overcooked.[2]

table.name: mem
table.column: This is the second highest rank of {QaS:n:1h}.

table.name: mem
table.column: This is a title for a warrior who has attained legendary status in life.
[1] {DS9 - Blood Oath:src}, [2] {A Good Day to Die:src}, [3] {Saarbrücken qepHom'a' 2014:src}

table.name: mem
table.column: a bird characterized by erratic, unpredictable behavior
This bird is similar to a {Da'vI':n}.
This is a reference to Donald Duck.

table.name: mem
table.column: a bird characterized by erratic, unpredictable behavior
This is a reference to Daffy Duck.

table.name: mem
table.column: "Little Debbie" is a brand of dessert snacks.

table.name: mem
table.column: The object is the thing being surrounded. {-Daq:n:suff} is unnecessary.[2]

table.name: mem
table.column: This can also refer to the suits in a deck of playing cards, for which see {meyrI':n}, {por:n}, {Sor:n}, and {'eSpeD:n}.

table.name: mem
table.column: This refers to a duty station on a ship, not to something worn on the head (which would be {mIv:n:1}).

table.name: mem
table.column: This expression may be based on {DeghwI':n}. In non-slang vocabulary, this idea can be expressed using a phrase such as {nab Hutlh 'ach vang:sen@@nab:n, Hutlh:v, 'ach:conj, vang:v}.[1, p.149]
This is defined as "act without a plan, improvise" in the word lists in the back of {KGT:src}, but as "take action without a plan, improvise" on {KGT p.149:src}.

table.name: mem
table.column: There seems to have been a verb {Degh:v:hyp,nolink} at one time with the meaning of "steer" which has fallen out of use.[2]

table.name: mem
table.column: For Klingons, this is preferred to {baQ:v:2}.

table.name: mem
table.column: Your face looks like a collapsed star!

table.name: mem
table.column: This is a {no' Hol:n} expression used by a captain upon taking command of a ship.

table.name: mem
table.column: Something which gradually vanishes (in terms of becoming less and less visible) may be said to {DemchoH:v@@Dem:v, -choH:v}. (Note that gradually does not necessarily mean slowly.) This might describe what people see when they are watching someone beaming away with a transporter beam. Once that person is gone, might use {ngab:v} to describe them. Using {loj:v} would be appropriate if one is focusing on the incremental disappearance of the person.[2]

This word was awarded to {Qov:n:name} as a Friend of Maltz, hence the Canadian spelling in the definition.
In {DSC - The Vulcan Hello:src}, the albino Voq's (see {voq:n:name}) skin colour was described as {Dem:v:nolink}.
The context for the explanation from {QelIS boqHarmey:src} is what would be the right word to use for the gradual disappearance of the Cheshire Cat.
When asked if this was a pun about democratic governments being more transparent, Marc Okrand has said that it was not. ({KLI mailing list 2021.07.28:src})

table.name: mem
table.column: This is also called {DenIbya':n:nolink}, typically by older speakers.[2]
This was defined as "Denebia" in {TKD:src}, but it was later clarified that this was an error and the English name of this planet is actually "Deneb".[3]

table.name: mem
table.column:
This creature is also called {DenIbya' Qatlh:n:nolink}.
Watch Gowron say this: {YouTube video:url:http://youtu.be/7qXuTn9HpP4}

table.name: mem
table.column: A Denebian is also called a {DenIbya'ngan:n:nolink}.

table.name: mem
table.column: She is a member of the House of D'Ghor ({Daghor tuq:n:name}).
[1] {DSC - Battle at the Binary Stars:src}, [2] {Saarbrücken qepHom'a' 2019:src}

table.name: mem
table.column: The suffix for the plural of this word depends on whether it is used to refer to beings capable of using language (see {-pu':n:suff}) or beings incapable of using language (see {-mey:n:suff}).

table.name: mem
table.column: This verb is also used idiomatically, so that for example {Deq SuvwI'@@Deq:v, SuvwI':n} is similar to the English expression "That warrior is history".

table.name: mem
table.column: veer (to the left or right while traveling or moving)

This means to change direction to the left or right while traveling or moving.
This verb can be applied to aircraft, for which see {Der:v:2}.[1]

table.name: mem
table.column: yaw (aircraft nose points left or right)
This is just the verb {Der:v:1} applied to aircraft.
The rud"der" controls the yaw on an airplane.

table.name: mem
table.column: "Dead Man's Chest", also known as "Derelict", is a fictional song from the novel Treasure Island.

table.name: mem
table.column: A writer's arm rests on his or her desk when writing.

table.name: mem
table.column: This word is used for both the body part and the handle of a {nevDagh:n}. Note that the suffix {-Du':n} is used even with the latter meaning.

table.name: mem
table.column: closet, cupboard, cabinet, fixed storage device
This does not necessarily have to be fixed in place.

table.name: mem
table.column: This is not a Klingon device as Klingons prefer live food, but refers to something found in many Terran homes.

table.name: mem
table.column: This is not defined in canon, but its meaning is inferred from its translation and components.
▶ {tlhIngan tIgh - SuvwI' DevmeH paq@@tlhIngan:n, tIgh:n, SuvwI':n, DevmeH paq:n} "The Klingon Way - A Warrior's Guide"

table.name: mem
table.column: If you're looking for someone named "Data", see {qoqyoq:n:hyp}.

table.name: mem
table.column: Knowledge of useful information may be unfortunate.

table.name: mem
table.column: This is a shortened form of {'ej De' vIchel:adv}. Klingon grammarians argue about whether the resulting {De'chel:adv} should be considered an adverbial in its own right.[1]

table.name: mem
table.column: There is a single word for both stalactite and stalagmite. If a distinction is needed, one says {pa' beb De'lor:n@@pa' beb:n, De'lor:n} and {rav De'lor:n@@rav:n:1, De'lor:n}. One never says {rav'eq De'lor:n@@rav'eq:n, De'lor:n}.
Data ({De':n}) and Lore are alike, and yet opposite.

table.name: mem
table.column: This term is normally used only for fairly big (or powerful) computers.[2]

table.name: mem
table.column: ▶ {qatlh Dat DI tu'lu', tlhIngan?:sen:nolink} "Why is there rubble everywhere, Klingon?"[2]

table.name: mem
table.column: In slang, "(first) dibs" means the right to something.

table.name: mem
table.column: This suffix turns a cardinal number into an ordinal number. For example, {wa'DIch:n:num} "first" from {wa':n:num} "one", {cha'DIch:n:1,num} "second" from {cha':n:num} "two", and so on. Ordinal numbers follow the noun to which they apply.

table.name: mem
table.column: An undertaker is someone who "dig"s. The slang phrase "infra dig" (from Latin "infra dignitatem") means "beneath one's dignity".
▶ {DaH nuq wIDIgh:sen:nolink} "What do we undertake now?"

table.name: mem
table.column: Its leaf ({DIghna' por:n:nolink}) is fried (see {mIQ:v}) by experienced cooks.[1, p.94]

table.name: mem
table.column: This is deep-fried (see {mIQ:v}) and eaten.[1, p.94]

table.name: mem
table.column: slide sword blade along opponent's blade

table.name: mem
table.column: use a pigment stick, paint with pigment stick

The object of this verb is the thing which is touched by a {rItlh naQ:n}, for example a {nagh beQ:n}. Since {DIj:v:2,nolink} is already associated with {nagh beQ:n:nolink}, it can be left out. However, if painting or drawing on something other than a {nagh beQ:n:nolink}, it should be specified.[2]
To specify the thing to be drawn, one can use the verbs {cha':v} or {nargh:v:0}. The latter means both "appear" and "escape", and similar to how {qon:v} is used for composing music or writing stories, its use suggests that the picture already exists and the {DIjwI':n} is somehow enabling it to escape and appear. Usually {nargh:v:0,nolink} is used with the suffix {-moH:v}, but it's also possible to use it without, though this construction is heard less frequently. The {cha':v:nolink} version is more common in informal settings and the {nargh:v:nolink} (usually {narghmoH:v:nolink}) version is more common in literature or in discussions about art.[2]
This verb can be used for producing a visual image even if no paint or pigment stick is involved, for example with a pencil, or with a device or computer software.[2]

▶ {DI'raq Dacha'meH nagh beQ yIDIj:sen:nolink} "Paint the stone panel with [a picture of] a sheep!"[2] ▶ {DI'raq Dacha'meH yIDIj:sen:nolink} "Paint [a picture of] a sheep!"[2] ▶ {DI'raq DanarghmoHmeH nagh beQ yIDIj:sen:nolink} "Paint the stone panel with [a picture of] a sheep!"[2] ▶ {DI'raq DanarghmoHmeH yIDIj:sen:nolink} "Paint [a picture of] a sheep!"[2] ▶ {narghmeH DI'raq (nagh beQ) yIDIj:sen:nolink} "Paint (the stone panel with) [a picture of] a sheep!"[2] ▶ {DI'raq Dacha'meH nav yIDIj:sen:nolink} or {DI'raq DanarghmoHmeH nav yIDIj:sen:nolink} "Draw a sheep on the paper!"[2]

table.name: mem
mem
table.column: This word is not defined as such in canon, but appears in the example from {TKD p.171:src}. This entry is here for ease of reference only.

table.name: mem
table.column: This is one of three key ingredients neede to make {ngat:n:1}.
In "Travels Through Spain" by Sir John Talbot Dillon, he describes various methods of making saltpeter.

table.name: mem
table.column: This is a traded commodity, like {qevaS:n}.
There is a genus of Terran flowering plants called the trillium. However, it seems that this word may actually refer to a mineral or perhaps a type of gemstone, although this is unclear.

table.name: mem
table.column: open entryway (to corridor, tunnel, conduit, Jeffries tube, branch of sewer)

This refers to the open entryway leading into a longish enclosed space, or in other words a {qa'rI':n} at or from which one can enter or exit. If there's a door there, the door is referred to by the usual word, {lojmIt:n}.

This is a private joke referring to a specific person.
The description originally given in the {KLI:src} New Klingon Words list says that if there is "a door that closes", then the entryway is "not a {DIn:n:nolink}" but "merely a {lojmIt:n:nolink}". However, this is an incorrect interpretation of the definition, as clarified subsequently.[2; 3]

table.name: mem
table.column: This is generally used for things spinning or rotating continuously or for a long time, while {jIr:v} is used when the thing rotates partially or once or for a few times. For example, one would {jIrmoH:v:2} the steering wheel of a car, while the tires {DIng:v:nolink}.[2]

MO implied at {Saarbrücken qepHom'a' 2011:src} that {DIng:v:nolink} is intransitive by saying that it works in the same way as {jIr:v:nolink}, but did not elaborate on the exact difference between the two verbs. The clarification was later provided in a message to the mailing list in 2021, which also confirmed that it is intransitive.[2]

table.name: mem
mem
table.column: This word takes the suffix {-Du':n:suff} when it refers to skin still on the body, and {-mey:n:suff} otherwise.[2] (But see {nagh DIr:n} for how to form the plural when it is used to refer to an animal shell.)

table.name: mem
table.column: When the context is clear, this is sometimes shortened to {DIr bID:n}.

table.name: mem
table.column: This is the name of a specific skin disease from the time of Kahless.

table.name: mem
table.column: This can refer to one pattern/design, or to a whole lot of them taken together.

table.name: mem
table.column: This is a drum made with animal skin stretched over a cylinder, usually over only one end. If skin is stretched over both ends of a drum, it is an {'o'lav:n}.[1]

table.name: mem
table.column: For "years ago" and "years from now", see {ben:n:1} and {nem:n}, respectively. For "years old", see {ben:n:2}.
▶ {tera' poH jaj wa', jar wa', jaj loSDIch, DIS wa'-Hut-Hut-chorgh. HovpoHvetlh latlh nab yIHutlh.:sen:nolink} "Save this Stardate: Sunday, January 4, 1998"[2]

table.name: mem
table.column: To "cave" (see {DIS:n:1}) is to give in to something under pressure. To "dish (out)" is slang for giving away information.

table.name: mem
table.column: There is no traditional Klingon way to say "Happy New Year", though a Klingon might understand {DIS chu' yItIv@@DIS:n:2, chu':v:1, yI-:v, tIv:v} or {DIS chu' DatIvjaj@@DIS:n:2, chu':v:1, Da-:v, tIv:v, -jaj:v} or {DIS chu' botIvjaj@@DIS:n:2, chu':v:1, bo-:v, tIv:v, -jaj:v}.[1]
Maltz thought "Merry Christmas" and "Happy New Year" were silly things to say.[1]

table.name: mem
table.column:
This is a day on which one recognizes or remembers an event which occurred a number of years ago. Other units of time are possible, such as {jarjaj:n} and {Hoghjaj:n}.
It's also possible to use other units of time such as {tupjaj:n@@tup:n, jaj:n} as a form of word play.
Both cardinal numbers ({DISjaj wa':n@@DISjaj:n, wa':n:num}) and ordinal numbers ({DISjaj wa'DIch:n@@DISjaj:n, wa'DIch:n}) are acceptable for referring to anniversaries.

table.name: mem
table.column: This is the name of a Federation starship.

table.name: mem
table.column: In {Star Trek First Contact:src}, Ruby was the name of a character in a Dixon Hill holonovel.

table.name: mem
table.column:
This word is used to refer to "the Federation", a shortened form of "the United Federation of Planets" ({yuQjIjDIvI':n}).
Coincidentally or not, this words sounds similar to {DI vI':n:nolink} "it accumulates debris".
The real reason {DIvI':n:nolink} and {DI vI':n:nolink} sound alike is because of the backfitting of {vaj toDuj Daj ngeHbej DI vI'.:sen}

table.name: mem
table.column: This means something is stuck like when you can't get a door or window open.

"Do It Yourself" is a term used to describe home improvement without the assistance of professionals.
This was defined as "be stuck" with an explanation, along with a bunch of other words which can be translated into various senses of "be stuck" in English.

table.name: mem
table.column: This means to review something for the purpose of making or suggesting changes.[1]

table.name: mem
table.column: This can be used for "personality" in the sense of a quality or trait that forms a person's character.[2]
▶ {meHghem yoS botlh DI'on 'oH ghommeH yotlhvam'e':sen:nolink} "This plaza is a feature of the centre of the Cultural District."[3]

table.name: mem
table.column: This is a fluffy, woolly, shaggy Klingon animal. A ram would be a {DI'raq loD:n@@DI'raq:n, loD:n}, and an ewe would be a {DI'raq be':n@@DI'raq:n, be':n}.
The Dirac equation failed to predict the Lamb shift.

table.name: mem
table.column: Contrary to the general pattern with {QeD:n}, this is written as two words. A person who does this is a {DI'ruj tej:n@@DI'ruj:n, tej:n}.[2]

table.name: mem
table.column: ▶ {DI'ruj velqa' nIqHom:n@@DI'ruj velqa':n, nIqHom:n} "virtual reality software"

table.name: mem
table.column: This is a {Qe':n} with a sign that says {moD Soj:sen@@moD:v, Soj:n:1}.[1, p.102]
This word is actually missing from the word lists. The definition comes from the definition of {tebwI':n:nolink}. The transliteration "Dok'e" is spelled that way twice and misspelled once as "Doke'".

table.name: mem
table.column: This describes a rather un-Klingon way to behave.

table.name: mem
table.column: How much do you want for that?

table.name: mem
table.column: This refers to the separator used in specifying a set of coordinates, and not to a specific coordinate point or location (for which see {Quv:n}).
▶ {He wej pagh Soch DoD cha':sen:nolink} "course 3-0-7-mark-2"[2] ▶ {He pagh-pagh-pagh-DoD-cha' yInab!:sen}

table.name: mem
table.column: There is an idiom {Dogh; tIghla' rur:sen@@Dogh:v, tIghla':n, rur:v}.[2, p.127]

table.name: mem
table.column: This consists of the words for "silly" and "defeat".

table.name: mem
table.column: back away from, back off, get away from
▶ {noH QapmeH wo' Qaw'lu'chugh yay chavbe'lu' 'ej wo' choqmeH may' DoHlu'chugh lujbe'lu'.:sen}[2]

table.name: mem
table.column: See {qawmoH:v} for an example of how to use a verb like this one.

This word is listed among other militaristic terminology in the body of {KGT:src} on p.48.
If this verb follows the example of {qawmoH:v}, then the subject of {DoHmoH:v:nolink} does the driving back, {-vaD:n} marks that which is driven back, and the object is the thing or location it is driven back from.

table.name: mem
table.column: This word can refer to people or otherwise. Even if referring only to beings capable of using language, one would normally say {Dojmey:n} rather than {Dojpu':n:nolink}.[1]

table.name: mem
table.column: mass, masses, multitude, a very large but indeterminate group of something
This word can refer to people or otherwise. Even if referring only to beings capable of using language, one would normally say {Dojmey:n:nolink} rather than {Dojpu':n:nolink}.[1]
The example sentence is a lip-match for {'ej DochmeywIj vItlhapqa'meH}.
▶ {'ej Dojmey wID, vInDa'ma' peq.:sen@@'ej:conj, Dojmey:n, wID:v, vInDa':n, -ma':n, peq:v} "He has killed many of our people."[2] ▶ {qoq De'wI' Dojmey:n}

table.name: mem
table.column: ▶ {DojneS mIplIj.:sen@@Doj:v, -neS:v, mIp:n, -lIj:n} "Your wealth is impressive, your honor."[2]

table.name: mem
table.column:
This is defined as "entity" in {TKD:src} and as "whole" in {TKW:src}.
The line from the {paq'batlh:src} was revised in the 2ed, and the word {Dol:n:nolink} no longer appears in it.
▶ {wa' Dol nIvDaq matay'DI' maQap.:sen} ▶ {wa' Dol bIH qa''e' porgh'e' je.:sen@@wa':n:num, Dol:n, bIH:n:pro, qa':n, -'e':n, porgh:n, -'e':n, je:conj} "Spirit and body are one."[3]

table.name: mem
table.column: To say that two or more things are parallel, this verb is used with a plural subject.[2]
The "go parallel to" definition suggests that this verb can be used transitively. However, the noun {HeDon} also suggests that {Don} acts like a verb of quality.

table.name: mem
table.column:
This refers to a direction like "left" and "right", and not to the side surface of an object which also has a front and a back, for which see {reD:n:3}.[4]
In {Klingon Monopoly:src}, {Dop:n:nolink} is used to indicate one face of a playing card.[3]

Based on usage, its homophony with {Dop:v:1}, and information revealed at {Saarbrücken qepHom'a' 2021:src}, this word refers to something which has a definite opposite side, like the "face" of a playing card or a polygon, as opposed to {reD:n:3,nolink}, which refers to the "side" of something which is more 3-dimensional.
This was defined as "side". The clarification "direction, face" was added to differentiate it from {reD:n:3,nolink}.
▶ {DopDaq qul yIchenmoH QobDI' ghu'.:sen}[2] ▶ {'echletHom Dopvam yIcha':sen:nolink} "card must be turned this side up"[3]

table.name: mem
table.column: The construction {DopmoH:v} is used for reversing a list.

table.name: mem
table.column: This is just the verb {Dop:v:1} applied to numbers in mathematics.

table.name: mem
table.column: Set fire on the side when there is danger.

table.name: mem
table.column: This verb also covers colors which would be called "brown". To differentiate a brown object from another object which could also be described using {Doq:v:nolink}, a phrase such as {Doq 'ej wovbe':sen@@Doq:v, 'ej:conj, wov:v, -be':v} is used.[2] The word {Doqqu':v@@Doq:v, -qu':v} refers to a color more red than orange.[3]

All natural languages found on Earth divide colours into "warm" and "cool" in the same way. Klingon distinguishes between {Doq:v:nolink} and {SuD:v:1}, but it groups "yellow" with the "cool" colours rather than with the "warm" colours.

▶ {HIq Doqqu':n@@HIq:n, Doq:v, -qu':v} "red liquor"[3] ▶ {Doq 'ej beqpuj rur:sen@@Doq:v, 'ej:conj, beqpuj:n, rur:v} (bright orange)[3] ▶ {Doq 'ej wovbe':sen@@Doq:v, 'ej:conj, wov:v, -be':v} "brown"[2; 4] ▶ {Doqqu' 'ej wov:sen@@Doq:v, -qu':v, 'ej:conj, wov:v} or {Doqqu' 'ach wov:sen@@Doq:v, -qu':v, 'ach:conj, wov:v} "pink"[4]

table.name: mem
table.column: The expressions {Doq bIQtIq:sen:nolink} ("the river is red") and {Doq bIQtIq bIQ:sen:nolink} ("the river water is red") can be traced back to an old drinking song commemorating the slaying of {molor:n:name} by {qeylIS'e' lIjlaHbe'bogh vay':n:name}.

table.name: mem
table.column: to be a particular shade of brown
A kradge has brown lips. This expression is used to describe an object which is a particular shade of brown (see {Doq 'ej wovbe':sen}).

table.name: mem
table.column: To be more specific about the shade of brown, a comparison is used. For example, one might say {Doq 'ej Qaj wuS rur:sen} (kradge lips are a particular shade of brown).[1]

table.name: mem
table.column: The object of this verb can be physical things such as a territory or a sword, or more abstract concepts such as authority.
Even though the definition says "territory", the canon usages show that this is just an example, and {DoQ:v:nolink} can be used to claim other things.

table.name: mem
table.column: sink for cleaning hands, face, food, etc.
A bathtub or swimming pool would be a {DoQmIv'a':n}. A {DoQmIvHom:n@@DoQmIv:n, -Hom:n} would be a bucket or anything similar.

table.name: mem
table.column: If necessary, "bathtub" and "swimming pool" can be distinguished using qualifiers: {Say'moHmeH DoQmIv'a':n}, {QalmeH DoQmIv'a':n}.

table.name: mem
table.column: The subject of this verb is a period or unit of time, such as a month. It should not be an event the ending of which one has some control over (for which see {van:v:2}, {ghang:v}).
▶ {tugh Dor qoSlIj. nom yIlop!@@tugh:adv, Dor:v:2, qoS:n, -lIj:n, nom:adv, yI-:v, lop:v}[2]

table.name: mem
mem
table.column: This idiomatic expression, which literally means to lose or misplace a target, means "to digress". {DoS vIchIl:sen:nolink} means "I digress", and so on.

table.name: mem
table.column: This is generally crafted from bone.

table.name: mem
table.column: This can have any number of wheels (typically two).
This is a reference to the D'Oyly Carte Opera Company.

table.name: mem
table.column: It is unclear if {tlhuch:v} "exhaust" means to "tire someone out".

table.name: mem
table.column: This is essentially the verb {Do'Ha':v} as a standalone sentence.

table.name: mem
table.column: This means the back of the lower leg.
"Git Along, Little Dogies" is a traditional cowboy ballad. "Dogie" is a regional US word used to refer to a calf (bovine animal) separated from its mother.

table.name: mem
table.column: This is the name of a planet which was disputed between the United Federation of Planets ({yuQjIjDIvI':n}) and the Klingon Empire ({tlhIngan wo':n}).

table.name: mem
table.column: This is a reference to the soap opera "Days Of Our Lives". The opening voiceover begins, "Like sands through the hourglass...".

table.name: mem
table.column:
The object is the thing which is improved.
This verb is used for improvement of a more abstract nature, such as in status, skill, understanding, etc. For improvement in a more concrete sense, see {rach:v}.[2]

table.name: mem
table.column: If it's in your way, knock it down.

table.name: mem
table.column: As a joke, this is missing from the E-K side of {TKD:src}.

table.name: mem
table.column: {nach Hom:n@@nach:n, Hom:n:1} is also fine, but {DughrI':n:nolink} is a more technical term.

table.name: mem
table.column: This can be used for a "setting" in a {SeHlaw:n}.[2]

table.name: mem
table.column: This is a type of {jem'IH:n}. This word can be used if the emphasis is to be on the elegance or grandeur of the building.
The Palatine Hill is one of the hills of Rome ({rom HuD:sen:nolink}).

table.name: mem
table.column: This is a Klingon animal found in the water which has a huge claw.[1]

table.name: mem
table.column:
This word can refer to any vehicle, not just spaceships, by specifying the environment in which the vehicle travels. See {puH Duj:n}, {muD Duj:n}, {bIQ Duj:n}.
Some special terminology is used for the parts of a {Duj:n:1h,nolink}. The section towards its {tlhop:n:1h} is called its {'et:n:2h}, while the section towards its {'em:n} is called its {'o':n}. To refer to a ship's dorsal, ventral, port, and starboard areas, see {Dung:n}, {bIng:n}, {poS:n}, and {nIH:n}, respectively.
For verbs related to ship movement, see under {'or:v}.
Known classes of Klingon ships include {neghvar:n}, {vorcha':n}, {qItI'nga':n}, {qISa'ruj:n}, and {toQDuj:n}.

table.name: mem
table.column: It is grammatically correct to treat this word as singular (a bundle of instincts) or plural (individual instincts).[2, p.27]

table.name: mem
table.column: DujDaj HubtaHvIS Hegh 'e' tul Hoch tlhIngan.
To die defending his ship is the hope of every Klingon.

table.name: mem
table.column: There is nothing shameful in falling before a superior enemy.

table.name: mem
table.column: ▶ {Dujmey law' DachIjpu':sen:nolink} "You have navigated many ships", i.e., "You are experienced".

table.name: mem
table.column: This refers to the geometric figure, and not to an astronomical body, for which see {Hov:n}.

This seems to be made up of the words {Duj:n:1} and {tlhuQ:n}.
The logo of Star Alliance, the largest airline alliance on Earth, is often painted on the tailfins of its members' airplanes.

table.name: mem
table.column: ▶ {ta'mey Dun, bommey Dun.:sen} ▶ {qIbDaq SuvwI''e' SoH Dun law' Hoch Dun puS.:sen}

table.name: mem
table.column: See {'aqroS:n:1} and {yor:n} for the top parts of an object. See also {lurgh:n} for other words related to spatial directions.

table.name: mem
table.column: This is a way to "dupe" your enemies.

table.name: mem
table.column: This is a bowl used for eating {chatlh:n:1}, which a diner pours into the {Duq:n:nolink} from a {maHpIn:n}.[1, p.99]
Norm Duke is the name of a successful American professional bowler. Also, "duckpin bowling" is a variation of "ten-pin bowling" using a smaller ball.

table.name: mem
table.column: This means in the sense of astonished, astounded, dumbfounded, shocked. It is stronger than {yay':v}

table.name: mem
table.column: This is said of good music or food.

table.name: mem
table.column:
This is used to refer to the spikes attached to {pogh:n}, {ghanjaq:n}, {'alngegh:n}, and so on.
For a stand-alone spike such as a stake, see {wIl:n}.

table.name: mem
table.column: This is used to refer to the little spikes found on the {Daqtagh:n}.[1, p.61]

table.name: mem
table.column: This term was not defined independently, but is inferred from {Duran lung DIr:n:nolink}.

table.name: mem
table.column: This is a food item. It never uses any plural suffix.

table.name: mem
table.column: This is a device which requires another device, like a key, or a code to open.
In Germany, locked doors found in public often have a sign saying "kein Durchgang" (no passage). Marc Okrand has said that this was not intentional.[1]

table.name: mem
table.column:
This is used for launching a {peng:n}.
The distinction between a {DuS:n:nolink} and a {chetvI':n:1} has to do with how the projectile is loaded.[2]

table.name: mem
table.column: This is the most general word for a place of learning.[2]
It's probably just a coincidence that this word looks like it's formed from {Du-:v} and {SaQ:v}.

table.name: mem
table.column: There is a Seinfeld skit about how one can't slam down a mobile phone, but must swipe or press a button ("doot").
▶ {toqwIn vIDut@@toqwIn:n, vI-:v, Dut:v:1} "I slam down the stamp."

table.name: mem
table.column: The earliest dice were made from bones ({HomDu':n@@Hom:n:1, -Du':n}).

table.name: mem
table.column: This refers to fruits or vegetables that come from a farm, as opposed to {naH tlhab:n}.[1, p.89]

table.name: mem
table.column: There is a typo in this sentence in {TKD:src}, an extra space right after {mIv:n:1}.

table.name: mem
table.column: This is bigger than your everday {Du'QamHom:n}.[1]

table.name: mem
table.column: This is the closest Klingon equivalent to a sunflower.

table.name: mem
table.column: This is the indentation just above the middle of the upper lip.
The cover of the Duran Duran album Rio features an iconic pair of lips.
